column4: anyone have software for Win XP that allows you to resize partitions?
I tried MPWE 7 but its not free
gparted on the livecd/liveusb
anything NTFS is windows related
gparted is an application. gparted doesnt "boot" what are you trying to boot
i have it on a live cd and i booted it
so you booted the normal livecd, and selected try ubuntu. then what
no, i booted it solo ... as in there is no OS booted up
gparted is an application. it is NOT an OS. what did you boot?
what is the link to the thing that you downloaded and burned?
gparted.sourceforge
so to echo Jordan_U thats not an ubuntu product. not the right channel for issues with it. but gparted is on the livecd, so just boot your install CD select "try ubuntu" and then you can use gparted
oh so i have to burn another live cd with ubuntu on it?
if you want help in this channel you need to be using ubuntu in some form
I am, the original problem was attempting to remove ubuntu from a dual boot
and someone told me to burn gparted, boot up with it and remove the partition
so do you have your original install media for ubuntu. b/c you can use that
no nor do I have for Windows either
first you need to boot windows and reinstall the windows bootloader. it used to be "fixmbr" i dont know if thats still correct
ok is that a program?
it is/was a windows command. i wouldn't trust me that its correct. i dont use windows
no you dont want that
you want this http://www.ubuntu.com/download/desktop
you are downloading Wubi. that thing you are looking at is wubi
oh, there was another link on that page that wasn't an exe
ok i see the confusion. you were using the thing at the bottom not at the top. thats the same as the link i sent you
so the top of my link or the bottom of your link should be fine. but you should be downloading a 700MB iso file
not an EXE
i would personally discourage that. i dont like the way wubi is structured. i think you are better off with dual boot or vbox, but not this weird wubi halfway house
Yeah, but the people who use the computer are not big Ubuntu fans and I want something thats easy to remove in any circumstance.
vbox would meet that "easy to remove" standard, and you have the benefits of a virtualized system (assuming your hardware is decent)
thats the problem, my hardware is far from decent, http://support.dell.com/support/edocs/systems/opgx240/en/ug/specs.htm
ok i burned the disc
so boot it, and select "try ubuntu"
when you have fully booted let me know
im fully booteed
open a terminal and run "sudo apt-get install mbr" then you can run install-mbr /dev/sda (i'm guessing that sda is correct but if you have one hard drive it should be)
you could verify that by checking "sudo parted -l" and identifying what disk has the NTFS partition
ok... mbr is a non-existent package
do NOT include the partition number in the "install-mbr /dev/sda" command just the disk label so "sda" not "sda1"
run software-properties-gtk and make sure that "univer" is selected
actually it doesnt even show up there. try "sudo apt-get update" and then try to install mbr
still
are you online in the livecd?
does /etc/apt/sources.list not include "universe"
nope
odd that they do that. but you can add a line. sudo gedit /etc/apt/sources.list copy one of the other lines but replace the bit after "precise" with "universe" and add it to the file
it says deb http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ precise universal
universe not universal?
so sudo apt-get update -- does it mention universe?
it says unable to find expected entry 'unisversal/binary-i386/Packages' to release file (wrong sources.list entry or malformed file
can you paste the error message and the contents of sources.list to paste.ubuntu.com
I AM INSTALLING MBR
sorry for caps
ok cool
I am setup
then sudo parted -l and look for the NTFS I suspect it will be /dev/sda# where the number doesn't matter to us
then you can run sudo install-mbr /dev/sda (without the number)
ok it says disk: /dev/sda
sudo install-mbr /dev/sda
thats it?

so now you can reboot and you should go directly to windows (no grub) confirm that. then reboot back to the livecd, and start "gparted" and use that to delete the ubuntu partition and increase the size of the windows partition. before you do that can you tell me if there was anything before NTFS on /dev/sda or was it /dev/sda1
ok thank-you
Windows boots up
im booting live cd again
ok. so now you should be able to remove the ubuntu and resize the NTFS provided you to not change where he NTFS starts
what do you mean by not changing where it starts?
if NTFS was partition 2 you should not remove partition1 and make NTFS grow at the front
NTFS meaning windows right?
yes
the windows partitions will appear as NTFS partitions in gparted because thats the type
k
do you know what you need to do at this point?
i just run sudo gparted right?
ok
gksudo is preferred
oh... its already open. So ill close it and run "gksudo gparted"?
damage is done
but with a livecd it doesnt matter so much because you can always reboot
thank-you. NTFS is sda1... i think its the first partition
should be. just select the stuff that is not the NTFS (and after it) and delete it. then select the NTFS and grow it to fill the free space
ok, does the non-NTFS part include the "D:/" drive
so check the types of the filesystems
how about file system "extended"?
ext4 is ubuntu. extended is a container for other partitions
Hey man
yes
I just wanna say thank-you for everything
I owe you alot
no problem. it wasnt a hard question, and that is what we are here for
lol that helps? oh and hi
i was assuming/hoping it would say the word proxy in there
